Infinite Series

Definition

Let (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) be a metric space and (Y,∥ ⋅ ∥Y)\p{Y, \norm{\:\cdot\:}_Y}(Y,∥⋅∥Y​) be a normed vector space. Let fn∈B(X,Y)f_n \in B\p{X, Y}fn​∈B(X,Y) be a sequence of functions. We say

  1. ∑n=1∞fn\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n∑n=1∞​fn​ converges pointwise if for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, ∑n=1Nfn(x)\sum_{n=1}^N f_n\p{x}∑n=1N​fn​(x) converges as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞.
  2. ∑n=1∞fn\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n∑n=1∞​fn​ converges uniformly if ∑n=1Nfn\sum_{n=1}^N f_n∑n=1N​fn​ converges uniformly as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞.
  3. ∑n=1∞fn\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n∑n=1∞​fn​ converges pointwise absolutely if for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, ∑n=1N∥fn(x)∥Y\sum_{n=1}^N \norm{f_n\p{x}}_Y∑n=1N​∥fn​(x)∥Y​ converges as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞.
  4. ∑n=1∞fn\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n∑n=1∞​fn​ converges uniformly absolutely if ∑n=1Nsup⁡x∈X∥fn(x)∥Y\sum_{n=1}^N \sup_{x \in X}\norm{f_n\p{x}}_Y∑n=1N​supx∈X​∥fn​(x)∥Y​ converges as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞.
Remark.

The main reason we want (Y,∥ ⋅ ∥Y)\p{Y, \norm{\:\cdot\:}_Y}(Y,∥⋅∥Y​) to be a normed vector space instead of just a metric space is because we need to be able to add functions together, and in general metric spaces, we don't have a notion of addition.

Also, in most cases, (Y,∥ ⋅ ∥Y)=(R,∣ ⋅ ∣)\p{Y, \norm{\:\cdot\:}_Y} = \p{\R, \abs{\:\cdot\:}}(Y,∥⋅∥Y​)=(R,∣⋅∣).
Theorem (Weierstrass M-test)

Let (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​), (Y,∥ ⋅ ∥Y)\p{Y, \norm{\:\cdot\:}_Y}(Y,∥⋅∥Y​), and fn∈B(X,Y)f_n \in B\p{X, Y}fn​∈B(X,Y) be as above. If YYY is complete (with respect to the metric induced by the norm), then (iv)   ⟹  \implies⟹ (ii).

Since R\RR is complete, the Weierstrass M-test will be our main way of proving uniform convergence of series for most problems.

Example 1.

Let fn(x)=xnf_n\p{x} = x^nfn​(x)=xn, where X=(−1,1)X = \p{-1, 1}X=(−1,1) and Y=RY = \RY=R. Show that ∑n=1∞xn\sum_{n=1}^\infty x^n∑n=1∞​xn converges uniformly on any compact subset of (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1), but not uniformly on all of (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1).
Solution.

Without loss of generality, we may assume that our compact set is [−r,r]\br{-r, r}[−r,r]. Indeed, given any compact set K⊆(−1,1)K \subseteq \p{-1, 1}K⊆(−1,1), we have

K⊆⋃r∈(0,1)(−r,r)K \subseteq \bigcup_{r \in \p{0, 1}} \p{-r, r}K⊆r∈(0,1)⋃​(−r,r)

so by compactness, there exist 0<r1<r2<⋯<rn<10 < r_1 < r_2 < \cdots < r_n < 10<r1​<r2​<⋯<rn​<1 such that

K⊆⋃i=1n(−ri,ri)=(−rn,rn).K \subseteq \bigcup_{i=1}^n \p{-r_i, r_i} = \p{-r_n, r_n}.K⊆i=1⋃n​(−ri​,ri​)=(−rn​,rn​).

Since KKK is closed, K=K‾⊆(−rn,rn)‾=[−rn,rn]K = \cl{K} \subseteq \cl{\p{-r_n, r_n}} = \br{-r_n, r_n}K=K⊆(−rn​,rn​)​=[−rn​,rn​]. Thus, if the series converges uniformly on [−rn,rn]\br{-r_n, r_n}[−rn​,rn​], then it converges uniformly on KKK also.

Now, let 0≤r<10 \leq r < 10≤r<1. Then

sup⁡x∈[−r,r]∣xn∣=rn  ⟹  ∑n=1∞sup⁡x∈[−r,r]∣xn∣=∑n=1∞rn<∞,\sup_{x \in \br{-r,r}} \abs{x^n} = r^n \implies \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sup_{x \in \br{-r,r}} \abs{x^n} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty r^n < \infty,x∈[−r,r]sup​∣xn∣=rn⟹n=1∑∞​x∈[−r,r]sup​∣xn∣=n=1∑∞​rn<∞,

since it is a geometric series with ratio ∣r∣<1\abs{r} < 1∣r∣<1. By the Weierstrass M-test, we get ∑n=1∞xn\sum_{n=1}^\infty x^n∑n=1∞​xn converges uniformly on [−r,r]\br{-r, r}[−r,r], hence on any compact subset of (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1).

To show that the convergence is not uniform on all of (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1), we proceed by contradiction. Assume that ∑n=1∞xn\sum_{n=1}^\infty x^n∑n=1∞​xn converges uniformly on (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1). Since the pointwise and uniform limits (when they exist) must agree, this means

∑n=1Nxn→N→∞11−x\sum_{n=1}^N x^n \xrightarrow{N\to\infty} \frac{1}{1 - x}n=1∑N​xnN→∞​1−x1​

uniformly on (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1). But ∑n=1Nxn∈B(X,R)\sum_{n=1}^N x^n \in B\p{X, \R}∑n=1N​xn∈B(X,R) and B(X,R)B\p{X, \R}B(X,R) is complete, i.e., uniform limits of bounded functions are bounded, which implies 11−x\frac{1}{1 - x}1−x1​ is bounded on (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1), a contradiction. Thus, the series does not converge uniformly on all of (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1).
Example 2.

Prove that ∑n=1∞nx1+n5x2\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{nx}{1 + n^5x^2}∑n=1∞​1+n5x2nx​ converges uniformly on R\RR.
Solution.

Our main tool is the Weierstrass M-test, so let's try to calculate

sup⁡x∈R∣fn(x)∣wherefn(x)=nx1+n5x2.\sup_{x \in \R}{\abs{f_n\p{x}}} \quad\text{where}\quad f_n\p{x} = \frac{nx}{1 + n^5x^2}.x∈Rsup​∣fn​(x)∣wherefn​(x)=1+n5x2nx​.

We'll try to maximize it using the first derivative test. Since fnf_nfn​ is an odd function, to maximize ∣fn∣\abs{f_n}∣fn​∣ on all of R\RR, we can just maximize fnf_nfn​ for x≥0x \geq 0x≥0:

fn′(x)=n−n6x2(1+n5x2)2=0  ⟹  x=n−52f_n'\p{x} = \frac{n - n^6x^2}{\p{1 + n^5x^2}^2} = 0 \implies x = n^{-\frac{5}{2}}fn′​(x)=(1+n5x2)2n−n6x2​=0⟹x=n−25​

Also,

fn(n−52)=12n−32>0.f_n\p{n^{-\frac{5}{2}}} = \frac{1}{2n^{-\frac{3}{2}}} > 0.fn​(n−25​)=2n−23​1​>0.

Now we need to prove that this actually gives us the global maximum of fnf_nfn​. Notice that

lim⁡x→∞fn(x)=lim⁡x→∞nx1x2+n5=0n5=0.\lim_{x\to\infty} f_n\p{x} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{\frac{n}{x}}{\frac{1}{x^2} + n^5} = \frac{0}{n^5} = 0.x→∞lim​fn​(x)=x→∞lim​x21​+n5xn​​=n50​=0.

(We're allowed to use limit laws since the limit of the denominator is non-zero.)

Thus, because fn(n−52)>0f_n\p{n^{-\frac{5}{2}}} > 0fn​(n−25​)>0, there exists M>0M > 0M>0 such that if x≥Mx \geq Mx≥M, then fn(x)<fn(n−52)f_n\p{x} < f_n\p{n^{-\frac{5}{2}}}fn​(x)<fn​(n−25​). The next part of the argument is a little tricky, so let me break it down into steps:

  1. If x≥Mx \geq Mx≥M, then fn(x)f_n\p{x}fn​(x) is strictly smaller than fn(n−32)f_n\p{n^{-\frac{3}{2}}}fn​(n−23​), so if fnf_nfn​ has a maximum, it must occur on the interval [0,M]\br{0, M}[0,M].
  2. [0,M]\br{0, M}[0,M] is compact and fnf_nfn​ is continuous, so fnf_nfn​ must have a maximum on [0,M]\br{0, M}[0,M]. In other words, fnf_nfn​ has a global maximum.
  3. Since fnf_nfn​ is differentiable on [0,M]\br{0, M}[0,M], the maximizer xmaxx_{\mathrm{max}}xmax​ of fnf_nfn​ must be a critical point, i.e., fn′(xmax)=0f_n'\p{x_{\mathrm{max}}} = 0fn′​(xmax​)=0.
  4. The only critical point of fnf_nfn​ is n−52n^{-\frac{5}{2}}n−25​, so xmax=n−52x_{\mathrm{max}} = n^{-\frac{5}{2}}xmax​=n−25​.

In summary,

sup⁡x∈R∣fn(x)∣=fn(n−52)=12n32,\sup_{x \in \R}{\abs{f_n\p{x}}} = f_n\p{n^{-\frac{5}{2}}} = \frac{1}{2n^{\frac{3}{2}}},x∈Rsup​∣fn​(x)∣=fn​(n−25​)=2n23​1​,

so by the ppp-series test with p=32>1p = \frac{3}{2} > 1p=23​>1,

∑n=1∞sup⁡x∈R∣fn(x)∣=∑n=1∞12n32<∞.\sum_{n=1}^\infty \sup_{x \in \R}{\abs{f_n\p{x}}} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{2n^{\frac{3}{2}}} < \infty.n=1∑∞​x∈Rsup​∣fn​(x)∣=n=1∑∞​2n23​1​<∞.

So by the Weierstrass M-test, the series converges uniformly on R\RR.
Example 3.

Show that ∑n=1∞n2+x4n4+x2\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2}∑n=1∞​n4+x2n2+x4​ converges to a continuous function on R\RR.
Solution.

Warning: It might be tempting to try to prove that the series converges uniformly on R\RR (since that would imply that the series converges to a continuous function), but this series does not converge uniformly on R\RR. Indeed, let f(x)=∑n=1∞n2+x4n4+x2f\p{x} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2}f(x)=∑n=1∞​n4+x2n2+x4​, and because all terms are positive,

∣f(x)−∑n=1∞n2+x4n4+x2∣=∑n=N+1∞n2+x4n4+x2≥(N+1)2+x4(N+1)4+x2.\abs{f\p{x} - \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2}} = \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2} \geq \frac{\p{N+1}^2 + x^4}{\p{N+1}^4 + x^2}.∣∣​f(x)−n=1∑∞​n4+x2n2+x4​∣∣​=n=N+1∑∞​n4+x2n2+x4​≥(N+1)4+x2(N+1)2+x4​.

(fff is larger than its partial sums, so we can drop the absolute value, and a sum of positive numbers is at least one of its terms, e.g., the first one.)

But

lim⁡x→∞(N+1)2+x4(N+1)4+x2=∞  ⟹  sup⁡x∈R∣f(x)−∑n=1∞n2+x4n4+x2∣=∞,\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{\p{N+1}^2 + x^4}{\p{N+1}^4 + x^2} = \infty \implies \sup_{x \in \R}{\abs{f\p{x} - \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2}}} = \infty,x→∞lim​(N+1)4+x2(N+1)2+x4​=∞⟹x∈Rsup​∣∣​f(x)−n=1∑∞​n4+x2n2+x4​∣∣​=∞,

so the series does not converge uniformly.

Instead, our strategy is to prove that the series converges uniformly on compact intervals. If we manage to do this, then given any x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R, there exists R>0R > 0R>0 such that x∈(−R,R)x \in \p{-R, R}x∈(−R,R), so

∑n=1∞n2+x4n4+x2 converges uniformly on [−R,R]  ⟹  f is continuous on [−R,R]  ⟹  f is continuous at x.\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2} \text{ converges uniformly on } \br{-R, R} &\implies f \text{ is continuous on } \br{-R, R} \\ &\implies f \text{ is continuous at } x. \end{aligned}n=1∑∞​n4+x2n2+x4​ converges uniformly on [−R,R]​⟹f is continuous on [−R,R]⟹f is continuous at x.​

This works for any x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R, so we would show that fff is continuous on R\RR. So, we need to show that the sum converges uniformly on [−R,R]\br{-R, R}[−R,R] for any R>0R > 0R>0. As before, our main tool is the Weierstrass M-test, so if x∈[−R,R]x \in \br{-R, R}x∈[−R,R], then

n2+x4n4+x2≤n2+x4n4≤1n2+R4n4  ⟹  sup⁡x∈[−R,R]n2+x4n4+x2≤1n2+R4n4.\begin{gathered} \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2} \leq \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4} \leq \frac{1}{n^2} + \frac{R^4}{n^4} \\ \implies \sup_{x \in \br{-R, R}} \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2} \leq \frac{1}{n^2} + \frac{R^4}{n^4}. \end{gathered}n4+x2n2+x4​≤n4n2+x4​≤n21​+n4R4​⟹x∈[−R,R]sup​n4+x2n2+x4​≤n21​+n4R4​.​

By the ppp-series test again with p=2>1p = 2 > 1p=2>1 and p=4>1p = 4 > 1p=4>1, we get

∑n=1∞sup⁡x∈[−R,R]n2+x4n4+x2≤∑n=1∞(1n2+R4n4)<∞.\sum_{n=1}^\infty \sup_{x \in \br{-R, R}} \frac{n^2 + x^4}{n^4 + x^2} \leq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \p{\frac{1}{n^2} + \frac{R^4}{n^4}} < \infty.n=1∑∞​x∈[−R,R]sup​n4+x2n2+x4​≤n=1∑∞​(n21​+n4R4​)<∞.

Thus, by the Weierstrass M-test, the series converges uniformly on [−R,R]\br{-R, R}[−R,R].
